content:
De Havilland is a British aircraft manufacturer that has designed and produced many iconic aircraft throughout its history. Some of its most notable designs, along with their distinctive features, are:

1. De Havilland DH.82 Tiger Moth - This biplane was designed as a primary trainer for the Royal Air Force and other air forces in the 1930s. It had a fabric-covered wooden frame and a open cockpit. It was known for its stability and agility, and thousands were produced for training purposes.

2. De Havilland DH.98 Mosquito - This multi-role aircraft was famous for its speed and maneuverability. It was made almost entirely out of wood, which made it very light and fast. It was used as a bomber, fighter, reconnaissance aircraft, and even as an experimental aircraft for testing new technologies.

3. De Havilland DH.106 Comet - This was the world's first commercial jet airliner, which first flew in 1949. It was designed with four jet engines mounted on the wings, and it had a pressurized cabin for passenger comfort. The Comet was a huge leap forward in aviation technology, and it ushered in the era of modern jet travel.

4. De Havilland Canada DHC-2 Beaver - This rugged and versatile utility aircraft was designed to operate in remote and harsh environments. It had a high-wing design and was made of metal, which made it durable and able to land on unprepared landing strips. It was used for bush flying, transportation, and even as a crop duster.

5. De Havilland DH.89 Dragon Rapide - This twin-engine biplane was designed for short-haul passenger transportation and was used by many airlines and air forces in the 1930s and 1940s. It had an enclosed cabin and was known for its reliability and ease of maintenance. It was also used for aerial surveys, photo reconnaissance, and even as a military transport aircraft during World War II.
